Fields.DialogueText: Verdun, I've been getting some concerning reports from the crew.
Vraiment? If it is a problem of morale, allow me to remedy it.
That's the problem. They're... how should I put this?
Afraid of me?
I'm a little concerned that you guessed it so easily.
Si je peux être honnête, Capitaine, your crew are not as fierce as they should be. I have witnessed hesitation and even fear in our battles with the Morganas.
This is war, and that's to be expected. But as long as they don't let it interfere with their work, it shouldn't be a problem.
And if they do, what then? That is where I volunteer myself. They must be brave hearts in one intrepid brotherhood.
There are rumors going around about your approach to boosting morale.
Idle talk and nothing more. I will have to teach them otherwise.
One of my sailors told me that you were planning to make them vote on who to throw overboard.
Quelle absurdité! It would be a waste of manpower.

Fields.MenuText: Whatever you're doing, can you tone it down?
I think you're missing the point.
I know you're trying to help, but don't scare them.

Fields.DialogueText: I may, Capitaine, but you must understand that the Morganas will not.
I am merely being realistic about our resources.
If a little sternness upsets your men, perhaps they are in the wrong line of work.
Save your intimidation for the Morganas. That's all I ask.
They do not intimidate easily, Capitaine. Sailors, on the other hand...
We're within striking distance of a Morgana. Focus on her.
@BATTLE
Verdun, have you noticed any... malaise among the crew?
Only that of cowardice, Capitaine.
I'm starting to realize where it's coming from.
Franchement, Capitaine, I wonder where you find your men. They do not seem to appreciate their appointed tasks.
What do you mean?
I was detecting the same malaise you complain of. So I assembled what I could of the crew and roused them with a stirring speech.
About?
A memento mori, if you will. Helpless among the living and the dead in the face of certain doom, what better way to distinguish oneself than with virtuous and zealous service?
I take it they disagreed.
There is just no inspiring some people.
We're coming up on Dismay now. Maybe you can inspire her to death.
@BATTLE
Verdun, what's that all over your uniform?
Capitaine, this is my battle dress. It would be a waste if it stayed clean.
No, I mean... what have you been doing, exactly? You look like you've been down in the engine room all day.
Correct. I have been performing my routine inspection of my turbines. We Guépard-class destroyers have learned the lessons of our predecessors' inferior machinery.
You do know we have mechanics for that sort of work?
Ils sont insuffisants. They do not feel leaks and ruptures as I do. I heal scrapes before they become wounds.
You are the ship, after all... but I wanted to ask your opinion on our progress in the Mediterranean.
In a word, Capitaine? Exécrable.
Excuse me?
Since setting out on this new patrol we have not found one Morgana. Every hour we do not take up our quarrel with the foe is an hour wasted.

Fields.MenuText: Let's not get ahead of ourselves. We don't know what they're capable of.
I guess it's true what they say about war being ninety percent boredom.
Battles don't start without reconnaissance, Verdun.

Fields.DialogueText: All the more reason to find out. But I know that if they can burn, they can die.
I suppose you're correct. I merely remain vigilant for the other ten.
They do not end without firepower. We need more and better patrols.
I have men watching the horizon round the clock. We'll find one.
... No need, Capitaine. She comes.
You're sure? Just how far away can you sense them from?
Never far enough.
@BATTLE
You had a late night, Capitaine.
Brushing up on this month's radio encryption keys. Is something the matter, Verdun?
Plutôt l'inverse, Capitaine. I simply wish to discuss our operations with you.
Specifically...?
I do not trust my ''allies,'' Capitaine. The Kriegsmarine and the Regia Marina were baying for my blood not so long ago. Now I fight alongside them.

Fields.MenuText: Aren't Belles above international disputes?
If we don't fight against our common enemy, we're doomed.
And we need to concentrate on the present moment, not what may happen in the future.

Fields.DialogueText: Belles are, but our capitaines are not.
We must face the Morganas, but not with our back to the Axis.
I have not met all of my sisters, but no Belle ignores the future. Neither should you.
I may one day die, but I would prefer to meet death head-on.
*ALARM*
That's the alarm.
Think on it, mon capitaine. "When it is peace, then we may view again / With new-won eyes each other's truer form..."
Now, where have I heard that before...?
Ask me when the battle is won.
@BATTLE
Verdun, do you remember our talk about crew morale?
Bien sûr. You chided me for not going easy on them.
Yes. Well, they still seem uneasy of late. Any idea why that might be?
I do not understand, Capitaine. I have eased my extracurricular training regimen, though I maintain that a five-kilometer run around the deck each morning is not so much to ask.
It is if I say it is.
Endurance cannot be neglected, Capitaine! The Morganas do not tire, and neither should the crew.
The crew aren't spirits. What have you been doing in the meantime?
Well, as strenuous physical exercise is not in the cards, I have been inspiring them with tales of my namesake battle, the better to stoke the faith and fire within us!
That sounds promising...
Absolument. The long hours and confinement at sea are nothing compared to the horror of Verdun. Trenches full of muck and corpses, with only the filthiest of water to drink...
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. We'd better get out there. Verdun?
Capitaine?
Try to be a little less... inspiring.
@BATTLE
There you are. Doing some light reading? I see you've raided my collection.
Your library is limited.
Well, you are a destroyer. Most of these books are about...
I am complaining about your library's depth, not its breadth. I will finish these within the month.
I'll see what I can do about that. You must be learning a lot.
''It is only one who is thoroughly acquainted with the evils of war that can thoroughly understand the profitable way of carrying it on.''
Sun Tzu.
Oui, although the American general Sherman put it more succinctly: "War is hell." Common sense.
Let's demonstrate that to the Morganas. We're closing on one now.
"It's gunnery practice out at sea..."
@BATTLE
Was there something else you needed to discuss, Capitaine?
Do you enjoy it? War? I mean, you are a destroyer...
Sans importance. Does your pen enjoy writing? Does your gun enjoy being fired?

Fields.MenuText: I suppose not. They're only tools.
What does that have to do with your idea of fun?
That's a little harsh. You're more than just a ship.

Fields.DialogueText: And so am I.
We are upon the sea to cleanse it. My idea of fun is none of your concern, nor mine.
C'est vrai. I am an intelligent ship. It is my duty to put your previous navies to shame.
You're certainly doing an admirable job. But there's more to life than war.
Pas pour moi.
Can I ask you a question?
You may ask another.
... Yes. You were built after the Great War, but you talk about it as if you remember it. How do you think that's possible?
Inconnu. All I can say is that we Belles are avatars -- not just of our ships, but of our countries. We have longer memories than any mortal man.
So when you talk about the Great War...
More than one hundred and sixty thousand Frenchmen died to win the battle that named me. Would you like me to name them?

Fields.MenuText: ... I'm sorry.
Their sacrifice speaks for itself.
Can you?

Fields.DialogueText: Do not waste your breath. The Germans tried to break France and failed. Death is a small price to pay for immortality.
And so shall ours, Capitaine, should the need arise.
Do not ask questions you do not want answered.
We have a Morgana inbound. Let's not be too quick to follow them.
We have that rare privilege of dying well, Capitaine. I will recognize that moment when it comes. Will you?
I hope we never have to.
@BATTLE
Do you remember everything about the Great War?
Non. Individual soldiers are only names to me. But I have approximations.
Approximations?
Germans would call it zeitgeist. I know the spirit, the mood of my country throughout its history. The Great War I feel most keenly.
It certainly has some incredible stories to it.
Do you know of the Christmas Truce, Capitaine?
Of course! Two opposing armies, laying down their arms to celebrate their common humanity...
A missed opportunity if ever there was one.
For what?
Can you think of another time when the enemy would let their guard down so flagrantly? Your forces would overwhelm theirs in a heartbeat!
During a truce?
Guns fire the same regardless. Why leave the slightest of openings for the enemy's?
But that's...
Do you know how fast a Christmas tree burns?
Faster than a man.

Fields.MenuText: I'm going to have to pretend I didn't hear that.
That probably wasn't the first thing on their minds.
Was that supposed to be a joke?

Fields.DialogueText: I will never understand you humans' selective approach to reality.
That is what I find strange. How does one simply forget their own mortality?
It was not my intent to amuse you.
... Let's just say you and I have a lot to learn from each other.
Peut-être. But a Morgana draws near, and there is no greater teacher than battle.
Humans are complicated, Verdun. Think about it.
He is dead who will not fight. Think about that.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, you wished to speak with me?
Concerning the Morgana we've been tailing today. She's leading us into civilian waters.
This is war, Capitaine. There is no such thing.
Not for the Morganas, Verdun, but we have certain constraints to abide by.
Such as?
The Morgana is within firing range of a fishing village on the Algerian coast. Until we're certain all civilians are evacuated, we don't fire.
C'est n'importe quoi. The village ceased to be safe for civilians the moment a Morgana set her sights on it.
You're not a Morgana. You're a Belle, and the rules of engagement are clear. Belles can't risk injuring bystanders.
What is the greater threat? An active Morgana or her swift destruction?
The greater threat is being mothballed! We need you on the seas!
Then let me defend them!

Fields.MenuText: We wait. I won't chance innocent lives for a kill.
I'm doing this for you. One stray shot and we're under investigation.
... Have it your way. It's on your head.

Fields.DialogueText: Merde! You mock war itself.
One stray shot and you're under investigation. You give the orders.
I'm glad we understand each other. I do not fire but to kill.
Whatever happens, Verdun, we're both complicit. Keep that in mind.
Fighting for our freedom, we are free. Keep that in mind.
@BATTLE
Target practice?
Quotidien. Tire!
*CRACK*
I like your diligence.
You have come to say something, Capitaine. Say it.
I wanted to commend you on that last mission. You did a fine job protecting the village.
Merci. Tire!
*CRACK*
You did it with minimal bloodshed, too. Too many humans would have settled for total war.
They are clear-sighted.
Sometimes you worry me, Verdun. War is brutal, but that doesn't mean we have to be.
Faux. War is attrition. War is a test. When the Germans attempted to bleed France dry at Verdun, she suffered ten percent more casualties, yet held firm for almost a year.
Every battle has its cost. But...
"A battle is won by the side that is absolutely determined to win." Tire!
*CRACK*
Don't quote War and Peace at me. I won't pretend that this isn't dark work, but no normal person revels in violence..
You have never understood me, Capitaine. I take no joy in killing. I do not seek out death. Belles are not human. They've no time for love and kisses.

Fields.MenuText: You're a person. There's more to you than killing.
What makes you any different from the Morganas, then?
And what happens when the war is over? What if you're sunk?

Fields.DialogueText: I wish I could agree with you, Capitaine.
I dress better.
Then I have fulfilled my purpose.
Tire!
*BOOM*
Are you out of your mind!? Using your main gun on a clay pigeon? I thought this was target practice!
Et c'est comme ça. A Morgana has volunteered.
@BATTLE
You sleep so seldom. It can't be good for you.
Some nights are later than others. It's part of the job. But I appreciate your concern.
Sound tactical decisions are not made by an exhausted commander. You endanger our mission.
I really should have seen that coming.
I have been thinking about what you told me.
Do you want me to sleep or not?
You weren't going to anyway. We may as well talk.
Of course. What's on your mind?
La victoire, comme toujours. But I sense that this is not always your priority.
Verdun, I'm your captain. Nothing on earth could be more important than our mission's success. The world depends on...
I want to believe you. Yet every day I have seen your mind elsewhere. You would not be here if you did not have a reason. Mine is victory. What is yours?

Fields.MenuText: To keep the world safe, of course. "If you want peace, prepare for war."
It's the least I can do for my country.
I guess I never knew any other way to be.

Fields.DialogueText: Vegetius, De Re Militari. You are a lifelong student.
Effectivement. You must be thankful for your home.
I see. I suppose I can relate, after a fashion.
Human history is cruel, Verdun. But there's so much more beauty to our world, even in the darkest of times. I think that's all any of us fight for - to make the world safe for it.
Even in the anguish of atrocious hours, you plan for the future. Even when you could die at any moment.
We will die. That's one of a few things all people share. There's little you can do to change it. So why obsess over it?
... I will have to think on this. But I am sensing a Morgana nearby. To victory, Capitaine?
Of course.
@BATTLE
Bon sang! Another slip and I will keelhaul you!
Verdun?
Give that to me. You cannot be trusted with it. And fetch more thread.
Can I have a word with you?
Merde! Sailor, do not open that...
*CREAK*
Excuse me, sir. I-I... Miss Verdun just needed help with...

Fields.MenuText: ... I'll come back later.
Verdun, were you about to try on that dress?
Hahaha!

Fields.DialogueText: Non! Capitaine, I apologize for my flagrant dereliction of duty.
Vraiment? I mean -- Capitaine, please forgive my indulgence! I was merely...
Capitaine, I can explain! This sailor's wife is my size and...
I was just trying to help Miss Verdun get into the dress. I had already seen to all of my duties and...
Slow down, both of you! Playing dress-up during downtime isn't against the rules.
Downtime is for the dead and prisoners of war!
Sailor, you may go. Verdun, stay where you are!
A Morgana approaches! I hear her singing in the night's abyss! Stand aside!
*CRASH*
Agh!
Mon Dieu!
... Verdun. Here, let me help you up.
Capitaine?
I'm not going to ask. Get ready for the battle. I'll buy you time.
Oui, mon Capitaine. Thank you.
@BATTLE
Verdun? Verdun! We're coming up on a Morgana!
Capitaine, I have neglected my duty. So since redemption comes through pain, permit me to redeem myself in battle.
I've told you before, you don't need to...
When things have died down, Capitaine, then we will discuss my... indiscretion.
@BATTLE
For the last time, Verdun, I'm not going to punish you for trying on a dress. You're a ship, so it's not like I can demote you.
I have concealed this from you for too long, Capitaine.
Concealed what? The fact that you like to dress up?
It is conduct unbecoming a soldier.
If anything, Verdun, I'm surprised. I didn't know you had interests outside of... well, outside of war.
Until recently, neither did I. It's... I...

Fields.MenuText: Take your time.
You don't need to justify it.
Trying to look good for some aircraft carrier?

Fields.DialogueText: It is hard to describe... unconventional.
There really is no doing so.
Was that supposed to be a joke?
It's a hobby. There doesn't need to be a reason.
That is easy for you to say. You are human. You have time to waste on such things.
And you don't? What else do you like to do?
... Pardonnez-moi. I have... drills to run.
I'm glad you invited me here, Verdun, but what was it you wanted to show me?
What you are about to see must be kept deadly secret. The sailor who was assisting me believes I guard his quarters each night listening for gossip.
Awfully convenient, these rumors.
Keep the enemy guessing about your men, and keep the men guessing about you. Regardez.
This is... this is some closet, Verdun.
Oui. Noble as it is, I do not content myself with my poilu's uniform... not in private, anyway.
Some of these fabrics are being rationed. There are places where you can't even get patterns like these.
I find them in ports around the Mediterranean from time to time. A young girl in the indolence of her youth...
Is this Verdun's coat of arms? Verdun, you didn't tell me you could sew!
Please do not be too impressed. It is knowledge common to every soldier. Trench warfare is hard on a uniform.

Fields.MenuText: This is amazing work. Why hide this?
We can't stay in uniform all the time.
There's no reason to be ashamed.

Fields.DialogueText: I am a soldier, not a seamstress. The crew should view me as such.
No matter how much we might want to.
I am not ashamed, Capitaine. Merely... apprehensive.
It's good that you're keeping busy. I like it.
You... you do? Ahem... Merci, Capitaine. Though perhaps we should focus on the Morgana to our northwest.
@BATTLE
Hard at work, Verdun?
Oui, Capitaine. Tire!
*CRACK*
Crack shot. Though I'd appreciate if you did this sort of thing while most of the men weren't eating.
I cannot let a single minute go to waste, Capitaine. Tire!
*CRACK*
If this is about your hobby, you can let this go. It hasn't affected your skills one bit.
I am my own worst critic, Capitaine. I know when I am slipping and when I am not.
Even so...
Tire!
*CRACK*
Like snowflakes falling on the Flemish clay.
On the subject of hobbies, was it you who borrowed my copy of Wedgwood's ''The Thirty Years War''?
You will have it back within the week. The Swedes just won Lützen. Tire!
*BOOM*
That'll be the Morgana. We'll save Wedgwood for another time.
Comme vous le souhaitez.
@BATTLE
Your book, Capitaine. Hard to believe Wedgwood isn't even thirty.
She's done more with her twenties than most people do in their entire lives. ''The Thirty Years War'' is an ambitious field of study.
She has found her passion as a historian. You can feel it in her prose. ''Vital decisions desperately thrust upon an underling...''
There's an urgency to it, isn't there?
And a self-sacrifice. She would make a good soldier.
Heh... perhaps. Not everyone can throw herself into a battle quite like you.
Capitaine, Belles fight because we must.

Fields.MenuText: Are you still thinking about the future?
There won't always be a battle to fight.
That doesn't make you any less extraordinary.

Fields.DialogueText: As Damocles with his sword, Capitaine. You humans push your expiration date back. My every success hastens it. It is in my nature.
Nor will there always be a need for us.
Nor any less temporary.
You're unique, Verdun. Perhaps the Belles will be the subject of the next great historical epic. We could be living it right now.
... Je ne sais pas quoi dire. Merci, Capitaine.
Looks like we have a Morgana in our sights. You can thank me the way you know best.
As we love ourselves, we hate our foe.
@BATTLE
Long day, Verdun?
Hopeful, high, courageous day, Capitaine. I have reintroduced the morning runs - abridged, but still meaningful.
How long do the men last?
At the normal pace, usually no more than two kilometers. Though I had one engineer match me for three this morning. I underestimated your crew, it would seem.
Perhaps a little music over the radio would keep them going.
Oh, would you, Capitaine? Saint-Saëns with the exercises would not go amiss. Beethoven's third, perhaps...
You've been lively lately, Verdun. I don't know what to make of it, but I like it.
Forgive the exuberance. I share my passions with no one else.
Not even your fellow Belles?
Certainly not. I must set an example for my sisters as I would your sailors. Each of them must be willing to sail into Hell at my side.

Fields.MenuText: With any luck that won't be necessary.
I don't think a penchant for sewing would change that.
Let's hope that's not what we're up against.

Fields.DialogueText: Luck is for those who do not accept fate.
I will take a soldier over a seamstress by my side any day of the week.
The Devil himself will fear the open water before the year is out.
Nobody tells your story better than you, Verdun. That's all I'm saying. Don't be afraid to tell it.
There is a Morgana inbound that I am sure would love to hear it.
... Was that supposed to be a joke?
Cherish it. I do not simply hand them out.
@BATTLE
You'll appreciate this, Verdun. Pope Pius XII spoke today about you Belles.
This ought to be good. What does His Holiness have to say?
The Church isn't saying you're angels. Then again, they're not not saying it.
Naturellement. They wait to feel out the true nature of the war. Are these the end times or aren't they? And where will they have the most to gain in either event?
What do you think you are?
I have never given it much thought. Humans are not content to let us serve our purpose.
You don't want to know whether you're a valkyrie or a selkie or whatever it is they call you?
On s'en fout? The Morganas come and we destroy them. Anyone who claims to have solved that mystery is a narcissist.
Humans aren't always so comfortable not knowing the answers. Why do you think we tell stories? Or make music? It's something to talk about.
Now I understand. You don't ignore your mortality after all. You're all afraid.

Fields.MenuText: Guilty as charged. Maybe that's what makes us special.
Or curious.
Don't tell me you've never thought about death.

Fields.DialogueText: The best artists are the ones too scared to remain silent... interesting.
Aucune différence.
Every day.
But it matters not. We Belles know why we're here. Win or lose, death is a merciful putting away of what has been.
You're not even a little invested in the outcome?
I admit you're making it difficult not to be.
Invest yourself in the battle today. We're hot on the trail of Avarice.
@BATTLE
Prepare for action!
@BATTLE
What's all this, then?
A celebration of today's victory.
That explains the flask and the music, but I didn't think you were one to celebrate.
The proper way to celebrate a battle is to win the next one. Even so, I understand humans are fond of wine.
Where did you get that?
No poilu is properly dressed for war without his pinard ration. Consider this an honor.
Do you have any glasses?
Blasphème. Drink from the flask or not at all.
It's a bit... rough.
So is war. Shall we dance?
Until recently, you would have thought this was a waste of time.
I am at peace with a moment of levity now and again. Great death has made all his forevermore, in any case.
The more things change...
Prepare for action!
@BATTLE
Something's on your mind.
How can you tell?
You always throw yourself into target practice to avoid difficult topics.
What's difficult? Tire!
*BOOM*
You're also using your guns on the clay pigeons again.
Vous ne dites pas.
I saw your face during the battle with Despair today. What did she say to you?
Tire!
*BOOM*

Fields.MenuText: I can come back.
I'm fairly certain that wasn't it.
Did she threaten you?

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, without you here I might turn my guns on the sea itself.
Your cleverness will get you killed one day.
Far from it.
What did she say?
It was not what she said. It was the way she said it. She spoke the standard Morgana things. Despair, self-preservation, hatred. All things I'm familiar with.
So?
So I've never believed a Morgana before.
You've never what?
Since I awoke, they've threatened everything they assumed I valued. I shrugged it off because there is no rest for the Belle. But Despair...
It occurred to you that there are parts of your life you would miss.
One can't let down one's guard for an instant. Who knows how soft they've become inside? We lie all sorts of ways and cannot sleep.
You'll just have to show the next one how hard you really are.
I've started taking the crew shooting.
Target practice?
I couldn't stand being alone with my thoughts. Worse than a Morgana.
Sometimes we're our own worst enemy, Verdun.
Yes. Which is why I barely spoke through the exercise.

Fields.MenuText: No speaking while training?
"Barely?"
You didn't share your misgivings with the crew?

Fields.DialogueText: Except to instruct them on technique.
I asked questions.
No need. They know what they need to.
My goal was simply to listen and to learn. They told me about their family, their friends, their hopes and dreams. It was enlightening.
Some of them have a lot riding on this war. Some just want to go home.
I maintain their perspective is limited. But if each man splits a skull to win my praise, I will limit mine.
Not too much, I hope -- a Morgana is hot on our trail.
Let us split her skull.
@BATTLE
Prepare for action!
@BATTLE
That's the last we'll see of Destruction for a while.
... I recognized some of those men.
They were French?
Some of the older ones, at least. She'd done... unspeakable things to them, but they were veterans of the Great War. Fought in the trenches of Verdun. To see them here...

Fields.MenuText: It doesn't get any easier.
Surely you're mistaken.
The Morganas don't care who you are. They just... take.

Fields.DialogueText: I did not know them personally, but I recognized their names, their faces.
Non. There is no mistaking the veterans of Verdun.
Now I understand what makes them so terrifying to you.
Humans fear death already as an unknown. To see it coming for you... to see a vision of what you will become... gently and slowly washing life away...
Good thing we have you to blow it all to hell.
Thank you, Capitaine. I needed that.
You saw she had prisoners?
Oui. Though they were already beyond saving.
Yeah.
Yeah, it's never pretty when a Morgana gets it into her head to have a human crew. You don't see it often, but...
We shouldn't see it at all.
No. Especially not when there's... surgery involved. For want of a better word.
Have you given any thought to what you'd like to create?
Besides a safer France for future ships to serve?
You enjoy books, music, anything that takes passion to create. What do you want to do?
I appreciate your interest in me, Capitaine. But my legacy is the safe waterways... my creation achieved through destruction. It is strange, non?
Verdun, I think I'm going to have to get you a notebook. You've already found what you love in among the insanity of this world. Wouldn't a Belle's diary be fantastic reading?
There is enough beauty in your world without my presumption to dictate it.

Fields.MenuText: You're not dictating anything. You're sharing yourself with the human race.
Oh, come on. You can't speak without quoting Great War poetry. You'd be a gifted writer.
Think of it as a way to survive after this is over. To survive in memory if not in body.

Fields.DialogueText: When a ship speaks, people listen.
We must burn that bridge when we come to it.
I prefer to focus on survival.
There are many things in your world I have come to love. There is music in the midst of desolation. But let me do what I do best. I am a destroyer. I destroy.
I think that's fair. We're closing on Calamity.
Though I shall never carve myself into the world's memory, I will carve myself into hers.
@BATTLE
You wanted to see me, Capitaine?
It's a matter that concerns you specifically.
Have I been pushing the men too hard?
No, you...
Capitaine, I swear those civilians were long gone. Regardless of how I feel, I...
Listen to me. I just want you to have this.
What... what is it?
Open it and see.
C-Capitaine...

Fields.MenuText: It's a picture I had made of you at the last port.
It's a diary.
It's a sewing kit.

Fields.DialogueText: I... I've never seen myself so... resolute.
For me?
Capitaine... I've been scavenging others' for so long...
A humble soldier cannot accept this. It would be favoritism of you to give it to me.
I'm the captain and you're my ship. There is no clearer favorite than you.
Why this? Why now?
Because at any moment you could sink to the bottom of the sea fighting the world's strongest navy. The world needs something to remember you by, to inspire it to fight on.
Like Verdun for France.
Like Verdun for France.
Capitaine... Merci. In all my dreams before my helpless sight... there is no greater reward than victory, and its closest cousin is memory. This means more to me than you can know.
You deserve it, and everything it represents.
There is a Morgana coming to break the peace, Capitaine. I will gladly make war.
@BATTLE
Was it really so glorious?
Was what really so glorious?
Verdun. The Great War. You speak almost glowingly of the experience.
I do not find joy in the fulfillment of my purpose, Capitaine. But I still believe the greatest test of man is carnage.

Fields.MenuText: Don't let my crew hear you say that.
I can see why that might be. There's nothing more horrific.
Ever the optimist.

Fields.DialogueText: Au contraire. They would do well to learn from me.
Adversity drives growth. Survive a bayonet charge and little else can cause you to waver.
Oh, but I am!
As with men, so with nations. The torn fields of France bloom all the more from their tilling with bombs.
So that's why you're not concerned with your own death. So long as you help ensure success, you'll have had a hand in the ultimate victory.
At last we understand each other! Though to tell you the truth, there are many things about this world I never thought I'd miss leaving behind.
It's the only world we have.
Perhaps. A Morgana approaches. Let's make the only world a little brighter.
Verdun...

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure what I would do without her.
She may be the most extraordinary woman I've ever met.
